column6: Looking at first two pages of google search

column4: The more blogs/tutorials there are means more information based on experience is available for developers
The more questions are on Stack Overflow the more answers. And more answers is more information on real life examples on how to use the API
Typically this will just be one

column6: These were only for the official documentation

column4: The more documents there are the more likely the documentation is complete. (Covers all the public methods in the API)
Each document should detail one part of the API if not one class/one method. Does each document have an usage example?
What are the total number of examples in the documentation? Generally the more examples the better as it gives developers many examples of how to use the API
How many documents have examples out of the total?

column2: Are the usage examples all the same?
column4: How many of the examples are different from each other? i.e., they show how to use a different part of the API?
column5: diff implementations of doing the same task
column11: Depending on Clone detection maybe we want to explore NLP

column3: diversity score (ratio of distinct to total)
column4: if it is higher, then we have more examples per task

column3: # of distinct tasks in the examples
column4: if we cluster examples by task and say get 5 clusters, then we have examples for 5 tasks in this library (we can go further and see all tasks mentioned in the lib doc and how many of these have examples but maybe that's another metric)

column3: avg number of example per documented task (that have e.g.)
column4: How many examples are there for a task?
How many of the tasks have examples?

column2: How much of the library is documented?
column3: coverage of public APIs in doc
column4: Maybe not just how much of the public methods are covered in the doc. But how many public methods actually have an example?

column3: which functionality of the library appears in the documentation
column4: What are the tasks the API is supposed to have implementations for?
column6: HTTP requests and response, HTTPClient interface, exception handling, Connection management, state management, authentication, caching.
column10: GET request, POST request, Concurrent requests, Configuration, Interceptors, Error handling, Request cancelling

column2: Does the documentation reflect the current state of the API?
column4: How different is the API with the docuentation?

column3: dates of unofficial documentation sources (grouped by year)
column4: The older the dates are the more likely it is no longer relevant

column2: What is the quality of code examples in the API?
column4: What is the quality of the examples themselves?

column2: Does the documentation provide any insight to the API other than how to use it? (Security, efficiency, size, incompatible other APIs)
column3: Document makes mention of these insights
column4: Does the API talk about meta information about itself?
